title: How to Completely Disable Google Chrome Updates

steps.title: Save any open work.
steps.content: Save any open work. You'll need to restart your computer at the end of this method, so make sure that you save any work before proceeding.

steps.title: Open MSConfig.
steps.content: Open MSConfig. You can use MSConfig to modify your Windows configuration and disable automatic updates. Use the following steps to open MSConfig: Press Win + R to open Run." Type msconfig into Run and press Enter .

steps.title: Click the Services tab.
steps.content: Click the Services tab. This is at the top of the System Configuration window.

steps.title: Check the "Hide all Microsoft services" box.
steps.content: Check the "Hide all Microsoft services" box. It's in the bottom-left corner of the window. Doing so will both cut down on the number of services listed here and prevent you from accidentally disabling an important Windows service.

steps.title: Scroll down until you find the two "Google Update Service" services.
steps.content: Scroll down until you find the two "Google Update Service" services. These are both by the "Google Inc" manufacturer and should be next to each other. You can sort by manufacturer by clicking the Manufacturer tab near the top of the window.

steps.title: Uncheck both "Google Update Service" boxes.
steps.content: Uncheck both "Google Update Service" boxes. Click the checked box to the left of each "Google Update Service" box to do so.

steps.title: Click Apply followed by OK.
steps.content: Click Apply followed by OK . It's at the bottom of the window. Doing so will disable both Google Update services and prompt you to restart your computer.

steps.title: Click Restart when prompted.
steps.content: Click Restart when prompted. Doing so will cause your computer to save your changes and restart, after which point Google Chrome should no longer automatically update.

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to update automatically. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here.

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+E to open File Explorer .
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + E to open File Explorer . It's the icon that resembles a folder. By default, it can be found in the taskbar in the lower-left corner.

steps.title: Ensure you have hidden files and folders showing.
steps.content: Ensure you have hidden files and folders showing. Depending on what type of installation you have, you may need to have hidden files and folders showing to find the Google Chrome update folder. Use the following steps to show hidden files and folders: Click the icon with three dots ( ⋯ ) at the top of File Explorer. Click Options . Click the View tab. Ensure "Show hidden files, folders, and drives" is selected. Click Apply .

steps.title: Open your local C drive.
steps.content: Open your local C drive. To do so, click This PC in the menu bar to the left, then click the drive just below it. It is usually "OS C:" or "Local Drive" or something similar.

steps.title: Navigate to the Google Chrome update folder.
steps.content: Navigate to the Google Chrome update folder. The Google Chrome update folder will be located in one of two places depending on whether you installed Google Chrome as an administrator or as a local user. Locate the Google Chrome update folder at one of the following locations: As an administrator: Open Program Files (x86) > Google As a local user: Open Users > User > [your username] > AppData > Local > Google .

steps.title: Rename the "Update" folder.
steps.content: Rename the "Update" folder. You should find the "Update" folder at one of the locations above. RIght-click the Update folder and click Rename . Enter a new name for the folder and press Enter . If you receive an alert that says the folder is being used by another program, press Ctrl + Alt + Delete and click "Task Manager". Click any program with the name "Google" in it and click End Task in the lower-right corner. Then, try to change the folder name again.

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to automatically update. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here.

steps.title: Open the Registry Editor.
steps.content: Open the Registry Editor. You can use the Registry Editor to make changes to your Windows configuration and disable Google Chrome updates. Warning: Editing files in the Registry Editor can cause permanent damage to your operating system or computer programs. Proceed with caution. To open the Registry Editor: Press Win + R to open run. Type regedit into Run and press Enter . Click Yes when prompted to allow Registry Editor to make changes to your system.

steps.title: Navigate to the "Policies" folder.
steps.content: Navigate to the "Policies" folder. Use the following steps to do so: Open the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE folder. Open the Software folder. Open the Policies folder.

steps.title: Create a new "Google" folder.
steps.content: Create a new "Google" folder. Make sure it goes within the "Policies" folder. Use the following steps to do so: Right-click a blank space within the Policies folder. Click New . Click Key . Name the new folder "Google."

steps.title: Open the Google folder.
steps.content: Open the Google folder. Double-click the Google folder in the menu to the side to open it.

steps.title: Create a new "Update" folder.
steps.content: Create a new "Update" folder. Make sure you put the new update folder within the Google folder. Use the following steps to do so: Right-click a blank space within the Google folder. Click New . Click Key . Name the new folder "Update."

steps.title: Click the newly created "Update" folder.
steps.content: Click the newly created "Update" folder. Click on the "Update" folder in the sidebar on the right to select it.

steps.title: Create a new "Updatedefault" value.
steps.content: Create a new "Updatedefault" value. Use the following steps to do so: Right-click a blank space in the "Update" folder. Click New . Click DWORD (32-bit) value . Name the new value "Updatedefault."

steps.title: Double-click Updatedefault.
steps.content: Double-click Updatedefault . This opens the "Edit" window.

steps.title: Type "0" below "Value data" and click Ok.
steps.content: Type "0" below "Value data" and click Ok . This sets the value data to "0", which tells Google not to update.

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to automatically update. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here. If this doesn't work try adding an additional DWORD file in the Google Update folder in the Registry editor named "DWORD: AutoUpdateCheckPeriodMinutes" with a value data of "0", as well as a DWORD named "DWORD: DisableAutoUpdateChecksCheckboxValue" with a value data of "1". [1] X Research source

steps.title: Open Finder .
steps.content: Open Finder . It has a blue and white icon that resembles a smiley face. It's in the dock at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Click Go.
steps.content: Click Go . It's a menu item at the top of your Mac's screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Hold down ⌥ Option and click Library.
steps.content: Hold down ⌥ Option and click Library . You should see it near the bottom of the Go drop-down menu. The Library folder will open.

steps.title: Open the "Google" folder.
steps.content: Open the "Google" folder. Scroll down until you find the folder labeled "Google", then double-click it.

steps.title: Rename the "GoogleSoftwareUpdate" folder.
steps.content: Rename the "GoogleSoftwareUpdate" folder. You may first have to click the lock-shaped icon in the bottom-left corner of the window and enter your user password. Use the following steps to rename the GoogleSoftwareUpdate folder: Click the GoogleSoftwareUpdate folder. Click File in the menu bar at the top. Click Get Info . Select the folder's name at the top of the window. Give it a new name (i.e., "NoUpdate"). Press Return .

steps.title: Restart your Mac.
steps.content: Restart your Mac. Click the Apple menu , click Restart... , and click Restart Now when prompted. Once your Mac finishes restarting, Chrome should no longer update automatically.

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to automatically update. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here.

steps.title: Open the Finder .
steps.content: Open the Finder . It's the icon that resembles a blue and white smiley face. It's in the Dock at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Click Applications.
steps.content: Click Applications . It's in the sidebar to the right. This displays all applications installed on your Mac.

steps.title: Right-click Google Chrome.app.
steps.content: Right-click Google Chrome.app . This displays a pop-out menu to the right. If you are using a Magic Mouse or a trackpad, you can double-click with two fingers or press Control while clicking "Google Chrome.app".

steps.title: Click Show Package Contents.
steps.content: Click Show Package Contents . This displays all the contents of the Google Chrome app.

steps.title: Open "Info.plist" in an XML code editor.
steps.content: Open "Info.plist" in an XML code editor. You can either double-click the file to open it in your default code editor, or right-click the file and select "Open With" and then select an app to open the file with. If you do not have an XML code editor, you can download xCode from here .

steps.title: Double-click the URL next to the "KSUpdateURL" key.
steps.content: Double-click the URL next to the "KSUpdateURL" key. The key names are listed in alphabetical order on the left. The URL is listed on the right below "Value".

steps.title: Change the URL.
steps.content: Change the URL. To disable the URL, change the URL to anything you want.

steps.title: Save the file.
steps.content: Save the file. To do so, click File in the menu bar at the top and then click Save .

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to automatically update. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here.

steps.title: Open the Terminal app on your Mac.
steps.content: Open the Terminal app on your Mac. Click the Mac Spotlight icon in the menu bar, type Terminal , and double-click Terminal to open it.

steps.title: Type the command to change the update interval and press ↵ Enter:
steps.content: Type the command to change the update interval and press ↵ Enter : This sets the Update interval to "0" so that Google Chrome stops checking for updates. The command is as follows: defaults write com.google.Keystone.Agent checkInterval 0 .

steps.title: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://settings/help in your Google Chrome address bar. Google Chrome will attempt to automatically update. If Google Chrome is unable to update, an error message will appear. If it says it is up to date, try one of the other methods listed here.

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings.
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which resembles a grey box with gears on it.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap App Store.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap App Store . This option is near the middle of the Settings page. Tapping it opens the App Store settings page.

steps.title: Tap the green "Updates" switch .
steps.content: Tap the green "Updates" switch . Doing so will cause it to turn grey. This disables automatic app updates, meaning that none of your apps—Google Chrome included—will automatically update from now on. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android's Google Play Store.
steps.content: Open your Android's Google Play Store. Tap the Google Play Store app icon, which resembles a multicolored triangle on a white background.

steps.title: Tap your profile icon.
steps.content: Tap your profile icon. It's in the upper-right corner. This displays the menu.

steps.title: Tap Settings.
steps.content: Tap Settings . It's near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Tap Network Preferences.
steps.content: Tap Network Preferences . It's the second option in the Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap Auto-update apps.
steps.content: Tap Auto-update apps . This menu allows you to manage auto-updates of apps.

steps.title: Tap Don't auto-update apps.
steps.content: Tap Don't auto-update apps . This will prevent all your apps from updating automatically. You will need to update your apps manually in the Google Play Store. [3] X Research source
